title: The Contemporary Object III: Chaos Theory
text: This chapter discusses the third contribution to the loop theory of the object that emerged in the 1970s with the study of nonlinear and complex dynamical systems, or “chaos theory.” Chaos theory showed that tiny differences in the initial conditions of how an object began moving or how someone measured it could create widely diverging outputs over time. Each object seems to follow a unique evolution that renders its precise prediction impossible. This chapter proposes an indeterministic interpretation of chaos theory. Some chaos theory interpretations say that there is an objective set of initial conditions, but we can’t know them. However, this chapter explains that we cannot know the precise initial conditions of any object in principle, due in part to quantum indeterminacy and entanglement. Chaos theory teaches us that each object has a singular trajectory that we cannot know in advance but tends to produce dynamic patterns over time. Studying these patterns of motion across different macroscopic scales can help us understand physical systems’ common features. This chapter shows that interpreting kinetic indeterminacy at the heart of the initial conditions of things is entirely consistent with and even beneficial for chaos theory.
